State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion Institute of Coal Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan Shanxi 030001 PR China Graphical abstract Hydrophobic SiO2-supported Fe-Ni bimetallic catalysts were synthesized by facile hydrothermal method, followed by grind-mixing process. The as-synthesized nanoparticles were appointed as robust catalysts in the methanation process to improve the calorific value of the natural gas. Notably, the functionalization of SiO2 surface with a hydrophobic layer was performed using a fluorinated alkyl group, as a critical step to prohibit the water-gas shift (WGS) reaction and consequently produce low amount of CO2 content during the methanation process. The obtained catalytic results demonstrated that Fe1.5Ni1.5 catalyst exhibited an excellent CO conversion of 95.2% at 320 °C with a natural gas calorific value of 56.4 MJ Nm−3, which is much higher than the previously reported results when traditional Ni-based catalysts used. Moreover, the modified hydrophobic catalyst exhibited a lower CO2 selectivity compared with unmodified one. This study provides a new and promising insight for the design and development of high-calorie SNG product. Keywords High-calorie SNG Fe-Ni bimetallic catalyst Hydrophobic SiO2 FTS reaction Methanation 1 Introduction Natural gas, the ideal fossil fuel, which is mainly composed of methane, has the advantages of easy availability, low cost and convenient transportation [1,2]. In recent years, and due to the depletion of crude oil resources and the environmental pollution caused by the burning of the fossil fuel, the development and utilization of new energy sources has become an urgent issue and in utmost need. Therefore, numerous efforts from the academic and industrial researchers have been directed to the production of synthetic natural gas (SNG) by methanation using coal or biomass-derived syngas [3,4]. Methanation is an important chemical reaction for the production of methane from syngas (H2/CO), initially used to reduce carbon monoxide in feed gas in ammonia synthesis [5]. Currently, many countries such as China, which are rich in coal but suffer from the deficient in oil resources, has been started to rely on the methanation process, as an ideal way to optimize the utilization and recycling of coal resources [6,7]. Generally, the methanation reaction is sensitive to some transition metal catalysts such as Pt, Ru, Rh, Ni, Fe, Co, etc [8–12]. Mills et al. have found that there is a specific order in the catalytic ability of these metal catalysts for methanation as following: Ru > Rh > Ni > Co > Pt > Fe [13]. Although the expensive Ru and Rh-based catalysts have more outstanding catalytic properties in the methanation process, however, from the economic point of view, and also the reasonable catalytic performance and availability of raw materials, nickel-based catalysts have become excellent commercial methanation catalysts and being widely used. Interestingly, Nickel-based catalysts, the traditional catalysts for methanation process, had been an advantage of highly methane selectivity [14,15]. Nevertheless, supported Ni-based catalysts using various oxide materials such as Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, etc., as catalyst support have been extensively studied [16–18]. However, the calorific value of SNG produced by nickel-based catalysts is very low due to the perfect methane selectivity (less than 40 MJ Nm−3). Indeed, the using of pure methane gas in urban cities is seems to be not familiar. And, in order to extend the application of natural gas in urban areas, it is meaningful and important to produce high calorific value SNG [1]. In a few countries such as Japan and South Korea, the imported commercial liquefied natural gas (LNG) has a much higher calorific value (41–46 MJ Nm−3) than pure methane natural gas [19]. Therefore, high calorie value SNG gas must contain a certain amount of light hydrocarbons (C2-C4) to increase the calorific value, which is often not achieved through the using of conventional nickel-based catalysts. The traditional approach used to increase the calorific value is being carried out through the addition of a certain amount of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) to methane [20]. However, the economic cost of this method is too high. Therefore, it is of utmost need to directly synthesize a high calorific value SNG by modifying the traditional nickel-based catalysts. Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) can selectively produce hydrocarbon directly from syngas (H2/CO) [21,22]. The typical active catalysts being used in FTS reaction are Fe, Co, and Ru metals, meanwhile, both of cobalt and iron have been commercially established in the industrial FTS application [23–25]. Therefore, the combination of methanation/FTS reactions is expected to provide the possibility for the production of high calorie SNG. For instance, Inui et.al have developed Co-Mn-Ru/Al2O3 catalysts and they found that the catalyst can effectively produce high-heat SNG (41.92 MJ Nm−3) by catalytic conversion of low calorific value gas (21.2 MJ Nm−3) [26]. Sun et.al found that Ni2CoO4 nanorods have extremely high activity (97.9%) and high calorific value (50.0 MJ Nm−3) at reaction temperature of 400 °C [27]. However, Co-based catalysts are superior to the production of the long-chain hydrocarbons (C5+) in the reaction, meanwhile, the formation of long-chain hydrocarbons increases the difficulty of pipeline transportation [28]. In addition, the continue increasing of the cost for cobalt metal has led to an increase in the total costs of the Co-based catalyst, which is restricted their large-scale industrial application. It is worth noting that, in addition to the advantages of the high availability and the low cost of iron-based catalyst, Fe catalyst has displayed an outstanding performance in the production of C2-C4 hydrocarbons in high-temperature FTS [29]. Lee et al. have investigated the catalytic performance of Fe-Zn catalysts in the methanation process and found that the Fe-Zn catalyst produced a syngas heat value (> 56 MJ Nm−3), which is higher than the reported results when traditional Ni-based catalyst is employed [20]. Fe-Zn catalysts showed high C2-C4 hydrocarbon selectivity and greatly increases the calorific value of natural gas. Iglesias et al. used K-promoted Fe-based FTS catalyst to convert CO2 and H2 from renewable electricity to form an alternative natural gas component (C1 68C%, C2-C4 30C%, C5+ 2C%) [30]. Later, our group has succeeded to synthesized ferrite catalysts for the production of high calorific value SNG using electroplating sludge as raw materials [1]. The results showed that the calorific value of natural gas synthesized by ferrite catalyst is as high as 41 MJ Nm−3, and the ferrite displayed high stability for a period of 300 h at 340 °C. Although, there have been several reports on the use of Fe-Ni bimetallic catalysts for the study of total methanation of syngas, however, there are few reports on the use of Fe-Ni bimetallic catalysts for the production of high calorific value SNG [19,31,32]. Therefore, studying the catalytic activity of Fe-Ni catalysts for the production of high calorific value SNG via the methanation process could be very interesting and promising from the real application point of view. Noteworthy, and unfortunately the use of iron-based catalysts in the hydrogenation reaction is mostly accompanied by a strong WGS reaction, which is strongly affected on the product quality [25]. Nevertheless, the methanation and WGS reactions can be monitored by controlling the production of CH4 and CO2, respectively, during the reaction. Therefore, it is necessary to reduce the CO2 selectivity by designing the high calorific value SNG catalysts. Thus, Yu et al. reported a CH3-modified Fe2O3@SiO2 FTS catalyst and they found that the selectivity of CO2 was reduced significantly due to the inhibition of WGS reaction [33]. Mudassar et al. have designed a Fe/ZSM-5 hydrophobic microcapsule catalyst and their study concluded that the thickness of silicalite-1 shell has a great influence on the WGS reaction, and the hydrophobicity of the catalyst surface increased, while, the CO2 selectivity is greatly reduced [34]. The ability to import the hydrophobicity properties to the support by simple chemical modification provides the possibility of reducing CO2 selectivity. In this work, we have successfully synthesized a well-dispersed and robust Fe-Ni/hydrophobic SiO2 catalyst using facile and highly efficient hydrothermal method, followed by grinding process for the production of high heating value SNG. The CO conversion, hydrocarbon selectivity, CO2 selectivity and the calorie value of modified catalysts with different [Fe]/[Ni] ratios in FTS/methanation reaction were investigated at different reaction temperature. We found that the ratio of the [Fe]/[Ni] is a critical factor in modulating the activity and selectivity of the reaction. The modified catalysts with hydrophobic SiO2 surface exhibits lower CO2 selectivity compared with unmodified catalysts. 2 Experiment 2.1 Chemicals All reagents used in the experiments were of analytical grade. Ferric chloride, nickel nitrate, sodium acetate, ethylene glycol, tetraethylorthosilicate(TEOS) and ammonium hydroxide (25.0%–28.0%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co.Ltd. Tridecafluorooctyl triethoxysilane (FAS) was produced by Aladdin. 2.2 Synthesis of Fe-Ni precursors with different [Fe]/[Ni] molar ratios Fe, Fe2Ni, Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2, Ni precursors (metal ions total concentration, 0.1 M; [Fe3+]/[Ni2+] = 0, 0.5, 1, 2 or 0.1 M Ni2+) were synthesized using a simple hydrothermal method. Typically, FeCl3·6H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and CH3COONa·3H2O were dispersed in 80 mL of (CH2OH)2 using magnetic stirrer. Subsequently, the solution was directly transferred into a 200 mL Teflon lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 200 °C for 10 h. After the reaction was completed, the autoclave was naturally cooled to room temperature, and the precipitate was centrifuged and washed with deionized water until neutral and dried at 80 °C for 10 h. Depending on the amount of Fe and Ni added, the samples were respectively represented by Fe, Fe2Ni, Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2, Ni. 2.3 Synthesis of hydrophilic SiO2 nanoparticles Hydrophilic SiO2 nanoparticles were synthesized by the well-known Stöber method [35]. Typically, NH3·H2O (4.5 mL) and C2H5OH (50 mL) were added to Si(OC2H5)4 (TEOS,4.5 mL) under vigorous magnetic stirring for 2 h. The resulting white solid was washed with deionized water for several times to neutrality and dried at 80 °C for 3 h. 2.4 Synthesis of hydrophobic SiO2 nanoparticles Hydrophobic SiO2 nanoparticles were synthesized according to the procedures described previously [36]. FAS(0.25 mL) was dispersed in a homogeneous SiO2 solution prepared by the Stöber method for 1 h with stirring. Finally, the hydrophobic SiO2 was dried at 80 °C for 3 h. 2.5 Synthesis of Fe-Ni supported catalysts The catalysts were prepared by mechanical grinding method as following. Different Fe-Ni precursors (0.2 g) and two different SiO2 nanoparticles (1.0 g) were added to the agate mortar. The added Fe-Ni precursor and SiO2 were mechanically mixed in a mortar for 3 min until the mixture be completely homogeneous. The sample was denoted as Fe-Ni-SiO2, Fe-Ni-FAS-SiO2, respectively. 2.6 Characterization of the catalysts Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was carried out on a MiniFlex 2 X-ray diffractometer with CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at a speed of 2°/min in the range of 5-85° for monitoring the Fe-Ni precursor phase. In-situ XRD during the reduction of Fe-Ni catalyst was carried out on D8 Advance (Bruker) diffractometer with Cu Ka radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The change in the phase of the Fe-Ni catalyst was monitored in situ at a scan speed of 2°/min in the range of 20°-80°.The morphology and size of the Fe-Ni catalyst nanoparticles were analyzed by using a field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JSM-7001 F) and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, JEM 2100F). Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES, Thermo iCAP6300) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250) were used to characterize the elemental composition and chemical valence of the catalyst. Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectra were measured on a FTIR spectrophotometer (Bruker Optics). The contact angle of the sample was tested by contact angle meter (SL200C). The reducibility of catalysts was monitored by temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR). The catalyst (60 mg) was heated up to 1000 °C at a rate of 10°/min in a reductive gas (H2/N2 = 5%) at a flow rate of 50 mL/min. The hydrogen consumption was recorded using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). BET specific surface, pore volume, and pore size information of the catalyst were obtained by testing using a TriStar II 3020 instrument. 2.7 FTS performance The catalytic performance was evaluated by pressing a mixture of catalyst (1.0 g) and quartz sand (1 mL, 60–80 mesh) in a fixed bed reactor. Before the reaction, the catalyst was reduced at 500 °C, 0.5 MPa for 8 h using pure H2 with the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 10Lg−1 h−1. The methanation reaction was performed at 320 °C under syngas (H2/CO = 2, GHSV = 5Lg−1h −1). The activity of Fe-Ni catalysts is monitored in the temperature range of 260–400 °C. The system pressure is maintained at 2Mpa during the evaluation of the reaction. The compositions of the reactants and tail gas were analyzed online by gas chromatography (GC) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The light hydrocarbons were analyzed using a capillary porapack-Q column with a flame ionization detector (FID). The methanation reaction takes a certain time to reach the steady state. The performance data of the catalyst was analyzed after 24 h of stabilization time. All catalysts were evaluated for 48 h. Unless otherwise specified, the data in the article is the mol% selectivity of the product. The CO conversion, the selectivity of CH4, C2-C4, C5+ and CO2 were calculated according to the following equations: (1) X C O = F i n × y C O ( i n ) − F o u t × K × y C O ( o u t ) F i n × y C O ( i n ) × 100 % (2) S C i = i × F o u t × K × y i , o u t F i n × y C O , i n − F o u t × K × y C O , o u t × 100 % i = 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 (3) S C 5 + = 100 − ∑ n = 1 4 S C n (4) S C O 2 = F o u t × K × y C O 2 , o u t F i n × y C O , i n − F o u t × K × y C O , o u t × 100 % where Fin, Fout refer to the volume flow of inlet gas (mL/min); volume flow of outlet gas (mL/min), respectively. yCO in, yCO out represents the CO volume fraction in the inlet gas; the CO volume fraction in the exhaust gas, respectively. K represents the correction factor. Ci (i=1,2,3,4) refer to CH4, C2H4, C2H6, C3H6, C3H8, C4H8, and C4H10, respectively. 2.8 Calculation of the heating value The heating value of SNG catalyzed by Fe-Ni catalysts were calculated by Eq.5. Only the calorie value of all hydrocarbons of C1-C4 was calculated during the calculation, and the influence of by-product CO2 (calorie value 0) was excluded. (5) H e a t i n g v a l u e M J N m 3 = ∑ i = 1 4 v o l u m e f r a c t i o n ∗ h e a t o f c o m b u s t i o n M J m o l s p e c i f i c v o l u m e N m 3 m o l o f h y d r o c a r b o n o f c a r b o n n u m b e r ( i ) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the Fe-Ni precursor The XRD diffraction patterns of the Fe-Ni precursors are shown in Fig. 1 . From Fig. 1a, it could be seen that the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 18.4°, 30.3°, 35.7°, 43.4°, 53.9°, 57.5° and 63.2° are corresponding to the (111), (220), (311), (400), (422), (511) and (440) crystal planes of the Fe3O4 (JCPDS Card No.75-0049). The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 18.4°, 30.2°, 35.6°, 37.3°, 43.3°, 53.8°, 57.3° and 63.0° in Fig. 1b are assigned to the (111), (220) (311), (222), (400), (422), (511) and (440) crystal planes of the NiFe2O4 nanoparticles (JCPDS Card No. 10-325). The diffraction peaks of Fe3O4 and NiFe2O4 NPs are corresponding to the cubic structures of the spinel phase. Noticeably, no peaks of any impurities phase were detected in the XRD pattern of NiFe2O4, which indicating that Ni2+ was incorporated successfully into the Fe3O4 lattice. On the other hand, the XRD diffraction pattern of NixFe3-xO4, NiO and metallic Ni nanoparticles are shown in Fig. 1c,d. From Fig. 1c,d, the peaks at 2θ = 44.5° and 51.8° are attributed to (111) and (200) crystal planes of metallic Ni (JCPDS Card No. 87-0713), while, the peaks at 2θ = 37.3°,43.4° and 62.9° revealed the (111), (200), and (220) crystal faces of NiO (JCPDS card number 47–1049). However, the remaining diffraction peaks are corresponding to the (111), (220, (311), (422) and (511) crystal planes of the NixFe3-xO4 [37]. The diffraction peaks in Fig. 1e are corresponding to NiO and metallic Ni, respectively. Interestingly, the intensities of the diffraction peaks for all catalysts samples are sharp and strong, suggesting the highly crystalline structure of all the produced nanoparticles. Obviously, when the proportion of Ni2+ increased, the diffraction peak intensity of metal Ni and NiO increased, while, the intensity of the diffraction peak for NixFe3-xO4 is decreased. The crystallite sizes of the prepared nanoparticles were calculated according to the well-known scherrer formula (D = Kλ/ β Cos θ), where K is represent the shape factor of particles, β is FWHM, λ is the X-ray wavelength, and θ is the Bragg angle. The particle size of the Fe-Ni precursors are calculated to be 23 nm, 10.5 nm, 13.5 nm, 25 nm, 32 nm, respectively. The content of Fe-Ni in the catalyst was analyzed using ICP-AES (Table 1 ). The ratio of [Fe]/[Ni] mass fraction of Fe2Ni, Fe1.5Ni1.5 and FeNi2 was estimated to be 1.85, 0.77 and 0.45, respectively. The texture properties of as-prepared Fe-Ni precursors were investigated using N2 adsorption–desorption measurements. Table 1 shows the values of BET surface area for Fe-Ni precursors. The BET surface areas of Fe, Fe2Ni, Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2 and Ni precursors were calculated to be 160.74 m2 g−1, 158.95 m2 g−1, 167.43 m2 g−1, 174.24 m2 g−1 and 44.69 m2 g−1, respectively. The pore diameters of Fe, Fe2Ni, Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2 and Ni precursors were calculated to be 4.70 nm, 10.20 nm, 5.48 nm, 3.40 nm and 6.62 nm, respectively. The pore volumes of Fe, Fe2Ni, Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2, Ni precursors were calculated to be 0.21 cm3 g−1, 0.41 cm3 g−1, 0.26 cm3 g−1, 0.19 cm3 g−1, 0.09 cm3 g−1, respectively. With the decreasing in the [Fe]/[Ni] molar ratio, the BET specific surface area of Fe2Ni, Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2 increased, and the pore size and pore volume showed similar trend of decreasing values. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of the Fe-Ni precursor are shown in Fig. S1. The isotherms of these Fe-Ni materials are classified as IV type, indicating the presence of a mesoporous structure in the Fe-Ni material. Among the five hysteresis loops, the other four should be classified as type H4 except that the Fe2Ni catalyst is classified as type H3. Indeed, H3 and H4 type hysteresis loops indicated that the microporous structure in these Fe-Ni materials is due to the formation of irregularly narrow cracks due to the accumulation of nanoparticles [38]. Notably, the existence of mesoporous structure in the catalysts may provide more active sites and thus improve the catalytic performance of methanation process [39]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was utilized to precisely differentiate the surface composition and valence state for the prepared catalysts. The Fe 2p XPS spectra of the catalyst precursors are presented in Fig. 2 . For all iron-containing catalyst precursors, the main peaks and corresponding satellite peaks of Fe 2p1/2, Fe 2p3/2(Fe2+, Fe3+) were observed in Fe 2p XPS spectra. The two peaks with binding energy at 710.6 and 724.0 eV are characteristic peaks of 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Fe2+ ions, while, the other two peaks with binding energy values of 712.6 eV and 725.8 eV are corresponding to Fe3+ 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 ions. The peaks with BEs of 718.8 eV and 732.4 eV are related to the Fe 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 satellite peaks, respectively. Interestingly, when nickel is incorporated into iron, a peak of metallic iron appears at the BEs value of 705.1ev, as shown in Fig. 2B–D. The Ni 2p XPS spectrum of the catalyst precursor is shown in Fig. 3 . For all nickel-containing catalyst precursors, the two main peak of Ni 2p1/2, Ni 2p3/2 and the corresponding satellite peaks were observed in the Ni 2p XPS spectrum. The two main peaks with binding energy peaks at 855.1 eV and 872.8 eV are characteristic peaks of Ni2+ ions of 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, and the other two peaks with binding energies of 861.4 eV and 879.6 eV are related to the Ni 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 satellite peaks, respectively. For the Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2 and Ni precursors, the peak of metallic Ni can be found at the BEs value of 854.6 eV. It can be seen from the XPS spectrum of Fe 2p and Ni 2p that the phase of Fe precursor exists as Fe3O4, while, the Ni precursor phase consists of NiO and Ni. The XPS spectrum of Fe2Ni indicates that the signal of metallic Fe is detected on the surface of Fe2Ni, but the signal of metallic Ni is not detected. This proved that the Fe2Ni precursor exists in the main form of ferrite phase (NiFe2O4), and the signal of metallic Fe may be related to the presence of a very small amount of iron on the surface of the sample. The Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2 phases are composed of NixFe3-xO4, NiO, metallic Fe and metallic Ni. The morphology of the prepared Fe-Ni precursors was investigated using scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The SEM images of the catalyst precursors are presented in Fig. 4 . It can be seen that typical spherical shape of Fe3O4 nanoparticles with an average size distribution of ∼200 nm is observed (Fig. 4A). However, nanocluster composed of small nanoparticles of 10–15 nm average size are formed for Fe2Ni precursor catalyst. On the same time, increasing the concentration of metallic Ni caused a small increment in the particle size for Fe1.5Ni1.5 and FeNi2 NPs to be in the range of 15–20 nm and 25–30 nm, respectively (Fig. 4C,D). Whereas, the ∼ 400 nm spherical shape formed by the aggregation of ∼40 nanoparticles in case of metallic Ni NPs, as can be seen in Fig. 4E. The above two topography are formed possibly due to the formation of NiO and metallic Ni, as confirmed through the XRD results (Fig. 1e). 3.2 Characterization of hydrophilic and hydrophobic SiO2-supported Fe-Ni catalysts It’s worth mentioning that, the WGS reaction increases the content of CO2 product, which in turn leads to a decrease in gaseous hydrocarbon content and a decrease in the calorific value of SNG. In addition, the presence of high CO2 amount in SNG can leads to a severe impact on the pressurized transport line during the commercial methanation process due to the pressurized condensation. Therefore, in order to increase the calorific value of SNG, we should inhibit the WGS reaction to reduce the CO2 content in the product. Since, the hydrophobic surface is one of the approaches to stop the WGS reaction, thus, we have successfully functionalized the surface of SiO2 NPs using FAS to prepare hydrophobic SiO2. The morphology of the silica before and after modification was characterized by SEM, as shown in Fig. 5 . From the figure, we can see that naked-silica is characteristic with its spherical shape and average particles size distribution of 220 nm, while, no significant change in the diameter after FAS modification is observed due to the low thickness of the new layer. The chemical nature of FAS-modified catalysts is analyzed by XPS and FTIR, as shown in Fig. 6 . From the figure, the XPS survey of the Fe2Ni, Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2 catalysts are corresponding to Si 2s, C 1s, O 1s, F, Fe 2p, Ni 2p. These detected peaks indicated that the surface primary compositions of these catalysts are Si, C, F, O, Fe, Ni (Fig. 6A). In the XPS spectrum of C 1 s, the peaks at 285.0 eV, 288.4 eV, 291.2 eV, and 293.5 eV are typical signals of -CH, -CSi, -CF2, -CF3, respectively (Fig. 6B). In the XPS spectrum of Si 2p, the peaks with BEs of 102.3 eV and 103.2 eV are corresponding to -Si-O-C and -Si-O-Si (Fig. 6C). Compared to the unmodified SiO2 and unmodified catalyst, the FTIR spectrum results of the modified catalyst showed two new shoulder peaks at 1026 cm−1 and 1240 cm−1, which could be attributed to the group -Si-O-C and -CF stretching vibration, respectively [40]. The results of XPS, FTIR are suggested that the SiO2 support surface was modified by the organic group of –(CH)2(CF2)5CF3. The morphology the Fe-Ni-FAS-SiO2 catalysts was monitored using transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The shape and size of the Fe-Ni-FAS-SiO2 catalysts synthesized by the facile grinding process are shown in Fig. 7 . From Fig. 7B,C, we can clearly see that the Fe-Ni NPs is attached successfully to the silica surface with a good dispersion properties. However, due to the synthesized Fe, FeNi2 and Ni nanoparticles have a large particle diameter, the dispersibility of the three precursors on the surface of SiO2 is not good. The unmodified catalysts executed the water droplet penetration test and the results are shown in Fig. S2. The results of the water droplet permeation test indicated that the naked-catalyst is not hydrophobic and the water droplets are quickly absorbed on the surface. The hydrophobicity of the modified catalysts was monitored by water contact angles experiment as shown in Fig. 8 . The water contact angles (CA) of modified-catalyst is measured to be 114.5°,123.4°,128.1°,110.7° and 120.7°, respectively. It can be demonstrated that the surface of FAS-modified silica has a hydrophobic properties. The FAS-SiO2 NPs was calcined in argon at 400 °C for 4 h and then subjected to a contact angle test (Fig. S3). The contact angle experiment showed that the high temperature did not affect the hydrophobic properties of the modified silica, and the contact angles before and after calcination were 141.7° and 135.7°, respectively. The phase evolution of FAS-Fe-Ni catalyst during the reduction process is monitored using in-situ XRD. As shown in Fig.9 A, the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 44.7°, 65.1°, and 82.3° are assigned to (110), (200), and (211) crystal faces of metallic Fe (JCPDS Card No.87-0721), while, additional diffraction peaks at 2θ = 30.1°, 35.4°, and 43.1° were detected and attributed to the (200), (311), and (400) crystal planes of Fe3O4 (JCPDS Card No.89-4319), respectively. This result confirmed that Fe catalyst is not completely reduced to metallic Fe at 400 °C. However, the observed peaks in Fig. 9B emphasized that the Fe catalyst at 500 °C has been completely converted to metallic Fe. On the other hand, for the Ni catalysts, NiO is completely reduced to metallic Ni0 at 400 °C, and the diffraction peaks detected at 2θ = 44.3°, 51.7°, and 76.1° are characteristic peaks of the (111), (200), and (220) crystal faces of metallic Ni0. For Fe2Ni catalyst, the phases of metallic Fe and Fe-Ni alloy can be observed in Fig. 9A,B. In addition to the diffraction peaks of metallic Fe, the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 43.5°, 50.7°, and 74.5° are corresponding to the diffraction of the (111), (200), and (220) crystal planes of Fe-Ni alloy(JCPDS Card No.47-1417) [41]. For the Fe1.5Ni1.5 catalyst, two phases of metallic Fe and Fe-Ni alloy can be observed in Fig. 9A. However, in Fig. 9B, Fe1.5Ni1.5 only shows the diffraction peaks of Fe-Ni alloy. Meanwhile, the intensity of the metallic Fe diffraction peak of the Fe2Ni catalyst in Fig. 9A is significantly higher than that of the Fe-Ni alloy. However, after reduction at 500 °C for 6 h, the diffraction peak intensity of the Fe-Ni alloy is much higher than the diffraction peak intensity of the metal Fe. This may be because the higher reaction temperatures favor the formation and crystallization of the alloy. For FeNi2 catalyst, a pure Fe-Ni alloy phase has been completely formed at a reduction temperature of 400 °C. Therefore, the in-situ XRD indicates that the reduction process of the NixFe3-x catalysts are as follows: N i x F e 3 − x O 4 ⟶ 400 ° C F e + F e x N i y ⟶ 500 ° C F e x N i y . As show in Fig. 9C, the diffraction peak of the XRD of the Fe-Ni alloy formed by the different Fe-Ni catalysts after the reduction was shifted. Taking the (111) crystal plane of the Fe-Ni alloy as an example, the (111) crystal plane diffraction peak of the Fe-Ni alloy formed by Fe2Ni catalyst is located at 2θ = 43.4°, the (111) crystal plane diffraction peak of the Fe-Ni alloy formed by Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2 catalyst is located at 2θ = 43.6°, 43.7°. At the same time, as Fe is gradually replaced by Ni, the XRD peak of the Fe-Ni alloy is gradually approaches the diffraction peak of metallic nickel. The shift of the diffraction peak position of the Fe-Ni alloy is very important, which indicates that the ratio of Fe atoms to Ni atoms in the Fe-Ni alloy formed by different Fe-Ni catalysts is different. The composition of the Fe-Ni alloy formed by Fe2Ni, Fe1.5Ni1.5, and FeNi2 catalysts cannot be accurately analyzed because the diffraction peaks may be the result of superposition of various alloy (FeNi, Fe2Ni, FeNi2) phases. It has been reported that various Fe-Ni alloy phases exist in Fe-Ni bimetallic catalysts [42]. The reduction behavior of the as-prepared catalysts was monitored via H2-TPR and the results are shown in Fig. 10 . For Fe catalyst, three reduction peaks were observed, as shown in Fig. 10a. The reduction peak centered at 340 °C is associated with the phase transformation from Fe3O4 to Fe2O3. The second broad peak between 400–620 °C represents the reduction of Fe2O3 to FeO, while, the third peak at 620–860 °C is corresponding to the reduction of FeO phase to metallic Fe [43]. However, for Ni NPs catalyst, a sole peak at 350 °C is detected, which corresponding to the reduction of NiO to Ni, and confirming the easy reduction of Ni metal compared with Fe catalyst, as shown in Fig. 10e. The H2-TPR curve of the NixFe3-x catalyst showed two reduction peaks. For Fe2Ni, Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2 catalyst, the first peak in the range of 300–420 °C is related to the dissociative reduction of NiFe2O4 ( N i F e 2 O 4 → F e 3 O 4 + N i O ) and the reduction of NiO ( N i O + H 2 → N i ), whereas, the broad peak in the range of 420–645 °C is mostly due to the reduction of Fe3O4 species( F e 3 O 4 + N i + H 2 → F e + F e x N i y ( a l l o y ) (Fig. 10b–d) [44,45]. Meanwhile, with the increase of Ni2+molar ratio of, the first reduction peak of Fe3-xNix catalysts is shifted to higher temperature and the second broad peak is shifted to lower temperature. This may be due to the increase in the molar ratio of Ni2+, and thereby, the composition of the catalyst has changed from NixFe3-xO4 to NiO. Noteworthy, the H2-TPR combined with in-situ XRD results confirmed that the phase transition of NixFe3-xO4 during the reduction process has undergone the following process: N i x F e 3 − x O 4 → F e 3 O 4 + N i → F e + F e x N i y . 3.3 Catalytic performance of the catalysts with the different [Fe]/[Ni] ratios The catalytic performance of Fe-Ni-FAS-SiO2 catalysts is summarized in Fig. 11 . It can be seen from the figure that increasing the reaction temperature is caused an increment in the CO conversion ratio and CH4 selectivity for all catalysts, but the C2-C4 selectivity is decreased. This is because the high temperature reaction is not favorable for chain growth, which resulting in product distribution to low chain hydrocarbon. It can be seen that when the molar ratio of [Fe]/[Ni] is 1, the catalyst exhibited the best catalytic performance. With the decrease of [Fe]/[Ni] molar ratio, the CO conversion of Fe-Ni catalyst increased at the first time and then decreased with a trend of change as following: Ni < FeNi2<Fe < Fe2Ni < Fe1.5Ni1.5. The CO conversion for Fe, Fe2Ni, Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2 and Ni catalysts are 96.4%, 97.0%, 95.6%, 96.9% and 64.8%, respectively at 400 °C (Fig. 11A). This may be attributed to the appropriate amount of Ni doping increased the dispersibility of the active component, which resulting in an increase in its reducibility. However, the excess amount of Ni2+ will form larger NiO particles, migration and sintering during the reduction of large particles of NiO, consequently, resulting in covered of parts of the active sites [46]. Notably, the Ni catalyst exhibited the lowest CO conversion ratio compared with all other catalysts over the entire temperature range. The reason for such behavior is maybe ascribed to the measured low specific surface area and the less area exposed active sites of Ni catalyst. On the other hand, with the decrease of the [Fe]/[Ni] molar ratio, the selectivity of the Fe-Ni catalyst to methane showed an increasing trend, and along with a change in the order of catalysts as following: Fe < Fe2Ni < FeNi2<Fe1.5Ni1.5<Ni. The CH4 selectivity for Fe, Fe2Ni, Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2 and Ni catalyst are 65.7%, 70.2%, 75.1%, 80.3%, and 91.3%, respectively, at 400 °C (Fig. 11B). The highest CH4 selectivity for Ni catalyst is mostly due to its sensitivity to the reaction of methanation. However, the recorded lowest CH4 selectivity of Fe-based catalyst is probably due to its sensitivity to low carbon hydrocarbon. Interestingly, Fe catalyst displayed the highest selectivity value of 30.5% of C2-C4 at 400 °C, meanwhile, with the increase of Ni to Fe proportion, the C2-C4 selectivity is decreased in the following direction: Fe2Ni > Fe1.5Ni1.5>Fe2Ni > Ni. The C2-C4 selectivity of Fe, Fe2Ni, Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2, Ni catalyst are 30.5%, 28.6%, 20.8%, 19.1%, 6.3%, respectively (Fig. 11C). Obviously, the component Fe has high selectivity to C2-C4 hydrocarbons. Therefore, the C2-C4 selectivity decreases as the ratio of Fe in the catalyst decreases. On the same time, the C2-C4 selectivity for all catalysts is decreased with increasing the reaction temperature. It was found that the catalytic performance of Fe-Ni catalyst could be adjusted through controlling the ratios of Fe-Ni interaction. In general, pure Fe is insensitive to the methanation process, but it exhibited high methanation activity when combined with Ni due to the formation of a double metal oxide or alloy compound [47,48]. At the same time, the catalysts formed by different [Fe]/[Ni] molar ratios have different tendency to form Fe-Ni alloys during the reduction process. Previous reports have been indicated that the formation of Fe-Ni alloys favored the methanation of CO [46,48–50]. However, in-situ XRD results confirmed that the different ratio of Fe-Ni catalysts may form different Fe-Ni alloys. Furthermore, the Mössbauer spectrum of the previously reported Fe-Ni catalyst indicated that the Fe-Ni alloy may exist in one or more forms of Ni3Fe, Ni2Fe, NiFe [42]. It is worth noting that the catalytic performance of Fe2Ni, Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2 catalysts is greatly different. This seems to indicate that not all Fe-Ni alloys can enhance the catalytic activity of the methanation reaction. Therefore, the formation of a suitable Ni-Fe alloy or a suitable ratio of different Fe-Ni alloys is a critical parameter to improve the performance of the methanation reaction. The formation of Fe-Ni alloy changes the adsorption amount of CO and H2 on the catalyst surface and therefore affects the activity of the catalyst. Tatsumi et al. have studied the hydrogenation reaction of Fe-Ni, Fe-Co and Co-Ni catalysts, and found that the alloy phase of Fe-Ni catalyst increased the conversion of CO and the selectivity of long-chain hydrocarbons [51]. It can be seen that the formation of the Fe-Ni catalyst alloy phase is particularly a critical issue in the methanation reaction. However, the catalytic performance of the Fe-Ni catalyst is the result of multiple active material interactions. The Fe-Ni alloy phase, metallic nickel, metallic iron and iron-carbon species have a great influence on the reaction. It is especially difficult to deeply analyze the mutual relationship between the various substances. This synergy between Fe-Ni may be due to the changes in the electronic structure of the catalyst to change the dissociative adsorption of CO and H2. However, there have been no reports so far on the mechanism of the Fe-Ni interaction to enhance the methanation reaction. This phenomenon requires further detailed study. The SNG calorie values produced from the catalysts are shown in Table 2 . From the table, the SNG calorie values of Fe, Fe2Ni, Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2 and Ni catalysts are calculated to be of 64.5 MJ Nm−3, 59.2 MJ Nm−3, 56.4 MJ Nm−3, 55.8 MJ Nm−3 and 50.1 MJ Nm−3, respectively. Fe catalyst showed the highest heating value due to the high C2-C4 selectivity compared to other catalysts. Meanwhile, compared to Fe, Fe2Ni, FeNi2 and Ni catalysts, it can be seen that the Fe1.5Ni1.5 catalyst displayed an excellent CO conversion at 320 °C (95.2%). This property is very powerful for Fe1.5Ni1.5 catalysts compared with the results obtained from the using of conventional methanation catalysts. 3.4 Effect of hydrophobic Fe-Ni catalysts on CO2 selectivity The effects of SiO2 surface properties of Fe-Ni-FAS-SiO2 catalysts on the catalytic performance and CO2 selectively are summarized in Table 3 . From the table, it can be seen that the hydrophobic Fe1.5Ni1.5 catalyst and the hydrophilic Fe1.5Ni1.5 catalyst exhibited the best catalytic performance at 320 °C, and the CO conversion ratio were 95.2% and 93.4%, respectively (Table 3). Noteworthy, all catalysts are exhibited a low selectively to long chain hydrocarbon (C5+), which provides the possibility of pipeline transportation of SNG. It is very important to note that the hydrophobic catalysts are significantly reduced the selectivity of carbon dioxide. Under the same reaction conditions, the CO2 (mol %) selectivity of the hydrophilic catalyst was 28.7%, 27.5%, 27.7%, 26.3%, 17.7%, respectively. However, the CO2 selectivity of the Fe-Ni catalysts with a hydrophobic surface was greatly reduced to 18.1%, 17.9%, 16.6%, 14.4%, and 8.99%, respectively (Fig. 12 ). This result indicates that the hydrophobic support may inhibit the water resorption to a certain extent and thereby suppress the WGS side reaction of the Fe-Ni catalyst in the reaction. Interestingly, the activity of the catalyst and the product distribution of the hydrocarbon were not affected before and after the modification of the support SiO2. Indeed, the results of this study are different comparing to the previously reported results of affecting CO2 selectivity by the preparation of hydrophobic catalysts [34,52]. The difference is mainly reflected in the activity of the catalysts. More precisely, the previously reported works have been concluded that the catalyst has a great reduction in the catalytic activity after surface modification compared with the catalyst before modification. However, and conversely, our results here showed that there is no a significant change in catalytic activity after modification of the catalyst surface with a hydrophobic layer (Table 3). The analysis suggests that the previously reported catalyst forms a core-shell structure in which the active material is surrounded by a hydrophobic carrier shell, which results in a portion of the active site being covered, further resulting in a significant decrease in the activity. Furthermore, the reports have shown that the formation of the core-shell structure caused a cover of the active sites of certain specific reactions, while adjusting the parameters such as the thickness of the hydrophobic shell and the pore size of the catalysts are critical to achieve product selectivity [53]. In this work, we simply mixed the Fe-Ni component and the hydrophobic SiO2 by mechanical grinding process. This method maximizes the exposure area of the Fe-Ni active site, while the hydrophobic silica support provides a hydrophobic environment. In fact, and un-like the reported works previously for using of core/shell NPs catalysts which affected by several parameters such as particles thickness, porosity and core size in its performance in the hydrogenation process, our grind-mixing method is not affected by such parameters, and this is the reason why the catalyst did not show any difference in its activity and product selectivity before and after the modification. In order to emphasize the advantages of our prepared catalysts in this study, we felt of significant important to compare the catalytic performance with other reported works previously for the synthetic of high calorific value synthetic natural gas, as shown in Table. 4 . The calorific value of natural gas synthesized by our Fe1.5Ni1.5 catalyst displayed the category of high calorific value synthetic natural gas. At the same time, the calorific value of our produced catalysts exceeded the calorific value reported by most of the literatures and even the calorific value of the commercial LNG. It is not difficult to find that when the active material of the catalyst contains Fe, high carbon dioxide selectivity is caused by the water gas shift reaction. It is an indisputable fact that the modified hydrophobic Fe-Ni catalyst reduces the selectivity of CO2. At the same time, Table. S1 shows that the Fe-Ni catalyst has no significant change in CO conversion rate and product selectivity within 48 h, which confirming the stability of our produced catalysts. It’s worth mention that, most of the reported works till now for using of Ni-supported catalysts in the methanation process were unfortunately produced low heating value due to the low ratio of C2-C4 selectivity from the reaction. Since, the ability to produce low carbon hydrocarbon is generally a significant factor for Fe-based catalysts. We found that the modification of [Fe]/[Ni] proportional can be tune the synergetic effect between Fe-Ni metals and then increasing the heating value of SNG. The catalysts with a hydrophobic surface properties reduces the WGS reaction, and consequently, solves the problems related to the high CO2 selectivity at high temperatures (> 300 °C). Moreover, the integrating of the active substance and the support material into one catalyst through the physical grinding approach to ensure that more active sites are exposed will guarantee that the activity of the catalyst during SNG synthesis is not affected by surface modification. 4 Conclusions In summary, a highly efficient and surfactant-free hydrothermal and grinding approaches were appointed to synthesize modified-SiO2 supported Fe-Ni catalysts with different [Fe]/[Ni] ratios to enhance the heating value of SNG. The obtained catalytic results showed that the conversion and selectivity of the as-prepared catalysts are different in the syngas methanation reaction. Among all of the produced catalysts, Fe1.5Ni1.5 catalyst exhibited the best catalytic performance of high conversion ratio (95.2%) and selectivity (CH4, 69.9%, C2-C4, 24.5%) at 320 °C. Notably, compared with the reported highest heating value (40 MJ Nm−3) through the traditional methanation catalysts, our produced catalysts showed much better calorific values of 64.5 MJ Nm−3, 59.2 MJ Nm−3, 56.4 MJ Nm−3, 55.8 MJ Nm−3,50.1 MJ Nm−3 for Fe, Fe2Ni, Fe1.5Ni1.5, FeNi2 and Ni, respectively. Importantly, Functionaliztion the catalyst support surface with hydrophobic FAS layer is the best approach for preventing the WGS reaction and reduce the CO2 selectivity. coredata.dc:description: Hydrophobic SiO2-supported Fe-Ni bimetallic catalysts were synthesized by facile hydrothermal method, followed by grind-mixing process. The as-synthesized nanoparticles were appointed as robust catalysts in the methanation process to improve the calorific value of the natural gas. Notably, the functionalization of SiO2 surface with a hydrophobic layer was performed using a fluorinated alkyl group, as a critical step to prohibit the water-gas shift (WGS) reaction and consequently produce low amount of CO2 content during the methanation process. The obtained catalytic results demonstrated that Fe1.5Ni1.5 catalyst exhibited an excellent CO conversion of 95.2% at 320 °C with a natural gas calorific value of 56.4 MJ Nm−3, which is much higher than the previously reported results when traditional Ni-based catalysts used. Moreover, the modified hydrophobic catalyst exhibited a lower CO2 selectivity compared with unmodified one. This study provides a new and promising insight for the design and development of high-calorie SNG product.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrophobic SiO2 supported Fe-Ni bimetallic catalyst for the production of high-calorie synthetic natural gas
